channel.title: Math Exponents (10th grade)
channel.description:
I have to evaluate to a single number. I really don't know how to do this, and i'm stressed with homework. If somebody knows how could you please help me. Thanks tons!
a. (y^3)(y^6) b.(5x^2y&4)(2xy^3) c.a^7\a^5 d.(5\3)^3 e.(pq)^3 f.(7p3q^2)^2 g.(7^3)^2 h.2\p^-4 i.-5^2 j.(-5)^2 k.2a^0 l.(2a)^0 m.4a^-2 n.(4a)^-2[br][size=1]Posted on: September 17, 2007, 09:17:43 PM[/size][hr]Anyone

item.title: Math Exponents (10th grade)

item.description:
@Unid_H4x0r wrote:

rotfl
(y^3)(y^6)
when you divid you subtract. so i guess you have to add the exponents mate?
y^9

how is this 10th grade hw?..

Read full topic

item.title: Math Exponents (10th grade)
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

Okay, you need to know the power rules.
Pretty much, when multiplying, add the powers. When dividing, subtract the powers. When raising to a power, multiply the powers =]

So (y^3)(y^6) is y^(3+6), which is y^9
a^7\a^5 is a^(7-5) = a^2
(7^3)^2 = 7^(3 * 2) = 7^6
(4a)^-2 = 4^(-2) a(-2) = 1/[4^2][a(-2)]

Read full topic
